newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Computer glitch shortens Philippine stock trading.
newsitem.headline: Computer glitch shortens Philippine stock trading.

text.p: A computer breakdown abruptly halted trading on the Philippine Stock Exchange on Thursday, stopping profit-takers from cashing in on high-flying thirdliners, brokers said.
The bourse suspended trading after 18 minutes of modest turnover with some orders failing to appear on the exchange's main computer network, PSE chief operating officer Rafael Llave told reporters.
Speculative oil and mining stocks, which have been soaring in the past few days, showed signs of succumbing to profit-taking, Audi Pantillano, an analyst at Angping Securities, said.

Among the biggest losers were Atok Big Wedge, which fell 80 centavos, or 15.09 percent, to 4.5; Ebecom Holdings, which shed 8.0 centavos, or 8.60 percent, to 85; and Araneta Holdings, which dropped six centavos, or 4.1 percent, to 1.40.
These issues had been rising on persistent rumours of upcoming real estate deals.
Raul Ruiz, vice president of Sun Hung Kai Securities, said the early selldown in speculative issues would not snowball since the counters would be easily picked up by bargain hunters.
The composite index shed 14.40 points, or 0.43 percent, to settle at 3,335.42 points before the bourse decided to suspend trading, making it the closing level for Thursday.
The Philippine stock exchange has suffered several computer breakdowns in the past. But brokers remained optimistic.
"Investors will still be buying depending on the market fundamentals and not on the efficiency of the computer system," Sun Hung Kai's Ruiz said.
